lines.text: [Momma sees Larry for the first time]
Who's this?
This is Cousin Paddy. He's coming to stay with us a while. Isn't that nice?

[suspiciously]
You don't *have* a "Cousin Paddy".

[to Larry]
You lied to me!
[Owen knocks Larry out with a frying pan to the head]
Momma! You're alive!
[to police]
Old people - you have to reassure them.
Where are you going?
I'm gonna kill the bitch. You want something?
Could you get me a Chunky?
Who the HELL are you?
I'm Owen's friend.
Owen doesn't have a friend!
That's because he's shy.
No he's not. He's fat and he's stupid!
You killed my wife, Owen!
No, I didn't... Yes, I did.
You're a sick man, Owen. You need care and I'm taking you to the police.
Did you know that Hawaii is a series of islands that was all spit up by the same volcano? I never knew that.
You killed somebody! You killed a person. You're a murderer. You took a life!
You're right. You're right, I'm no good. How could I do that? I'm a sick pers... cows!
[points at passing billboard]
Get out of my way, you black bastard!
What?
The night was dry, yet it was raining.

[teaching a creative-writing class]
This is a real classic by Mr. Pinsky. It's entitled "One Hundred Girls I'd Like to Pork."
"Pork"?
It's a coffee table book.
The Oriental Laker Girl. Chapter Seven... Mr. Pinsky, this is not literature!
Well, you know, I would put in photographs, a brief character sketch, like a biography, and a nice dust jacket.
Mr. Pinsky, what is this?
It's literature. It's a fantasy. My fantasy. Like Melville, this is my great white whale.
It's whacking material.
Isn't that literature?
Mr. Pinsky, how do you associate "Moby Dick" to a list of women you'd like to have sex with?
Well, I think it's very brave.
I think he's vulgar.
That's what they said about Twain.
That's what I'm saying about him.
I think you're vulgar.
I think you're a no-talent little shit.
Maybe I should change the title.
I like the title!

[bell rings]
OK, I'll see you Wednesday, class. Good work today. Remember, a writer writes, always.
[as the students prepare to leave, voices are heard saying "Pinsky, I could do the photographs" and "Hey Pinsky, what about Vanna White?"]

[on the phone with Owen from Hawaii]
Owen, what the hell did you do to my wife?
Ehh, I don't want to say over the phone. All I can tell ya is that I killed her last night.
[hangs up]
He didn't do it!
Well then who do you suppose did?

[after a pause to think]
Somebody else!

[On why he thinks Larry didn't kill his ex-wife]
All his life, Larry never did... anything.
Owen! Food!
In a minute, Momma.
Don't you "In a minute, Momma" me! Get off your fat little ass or I'll break it for you! I want two soft boiled eggs, white toast, and some of that grape jelly god damn it! And don't burn the toast!
Kill her, Larry.
He's trying to kill me! I asked for the salted nuts. He brought me the unsalted nuts. The unsalted nuts make me choke!
Your friend had an accident, he's dead! You go bowling and leave a corpse to take care of me!
He's dead?
See for yourself.
Larry! My friend, my friend... Larry!
"My friend! My friend!" You big crybaby. Go bury him in the yard before he stinks up the place.

[reading her manuscript]
His guts oozed nice, like a melted malted.
Hate makes you impotent, Love makes you crazy, somewhere in the middle you can survive.
[Larry's been hit in the groin by Momma's cane]

[in pain]
She's not a woman, she's The Terminator.
The night was humid."
[Closes the paper]
Class dismissed. I have a enormous headache in my eye.
Holy Shit! What a dream I was having! Louis Armstrong was trying to kill me!
Mrs. Lift?
Get away from me, you horse's ass!
[Hits Larry in the crotch with her cane. Larry falls to the floor, groaning]

[to Owen]
She's not a woman... she's the Terminator.
Larry! I can't breath!
Yes! That's because I'm choking you!
Owen, you gotta get it through your thick head. I may be a lot of things, but I'm not a killer.
You don't have to blow her brains out or anything.

[Sarcastically]
Thank you, that takes the pressure right off.
She's old. She's got a bad ticker. All you gotta do is jerk around a lot when you talk to her.
[Mimics shaking Mrs. Lift viciously]
"Nice to meet you, Mrs. Lift!"
Would you stop it?
Well just meet her. Maybe she'll be somebody you'd LIKE to kill.
"Dive... DIVE" yelled the captain through the thing. So the captain pressed a button, or something, and it dove. And the enemy was foiled again!
He called her a very bad name, and said "I hate her! I wish she were dead!"
You were writing a letter.
No, Momma!
You are writing to tell them to take me away! You want them to take me away!
I'm writing a story for class, Momma! I don't want them to take you away!
Yes, you do!
Owen loves his Momma!

[to herself]
Owen loves his Momma!
[singing mockingly]
Owen loves his Momma, Owen loves his Momma, Owen loves his Momma, Owen loves his Momma...
[Owen is typing on his typewriter when Momma comes and slams his hands on the keyboard]
Stop it, damn it! I got a wax ball in my ear. Get it out.
[Cut to bathroom. Momma slaps Owen]
Oh, Momma...
You're writing to her, aren't you Owen?
Don't start that again, Momma, and don't hit me anymore!
You love her.
There's no "her", Momma.
[Momma bends down above the bathtub as Owen brushes her hair back]
You're writing a letter!
I'm writing a story for class, Momma. Don't you see? I take a class, I take a nice class.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
And I'm gonna be a writer someday.
You know how that typing upsets me!
I'm sorry, Momma. A writer writes.
You're gonna be nothing. You're gonna be nothing. You'll never get to first base. All you do is type, type, type, type, type, type. You sit there typing all day like a fat little pigeon.
[Owen notices a pair of long scissors on a nearby shelf, picks them up and raises them]
You won't ever hear it again, Momma. I promise.
[Owen stabs Momma through the ear with the scissors. Momma stands up screaming]

[Confused]
Momma...

[Cleaning her ear]
I think you got it, sonny.
[Owen suddenly comes to his senses, realising he was imagining killing her]
I don't know what I'd do without you, Owen baby.
[Kisses him on the cheek and hugs him]
I know, Momma. I know.
Owen, my little baby. Owen, my little baby boy.
[Owen still looks confused as to how he cleared Momma's ear]
Slut! She's a slut! Look at her! Slut!
Why did you kill my wife?

I thought you wanted me to. That was the deal we made that night. You told me that hated your wife. You wished she was dead. I told you I hated my mama. I told you I wished she was dead. To told me to see that Hitchcock film about swaping murders. I figured I kill your wife and you kill my mama. That's fair.
I am not killing your mother. You have to turn yourself in.
I'm not turning myself in. That's not part of the plan.
What plan? There was never any plan, you moron! I am taking you to the police and you are telling them what you did! That's it and that's all! I don't want to hear another word!
If you take me to the cops, I'll just tell them that you did it Larry! What's the point trying to convince them that I did it all on my own? You've got the motive!
One little murder and I'm Jack the Ripper.
Remember, a writer writes always.

[Larry has driven his car off the road and it's going downhill through a load of bushes. Sat next to him in the passenger seat is Owen]
This is good. It's like the Flintstones car wash.

[talking at Margaret Donner on TV]
It's my life, Margaret. It's MY life and I want it back!

[referring to Owen's lousy murder mystery paper]
It wasn't motivated.
Sure it was. The guy in the hat killed the other guy in the hat.

[discussing Larry's stalled book]
Man, you been on "The night was... " for six months!
Takes place in the Yukon.

[last line, while they are snorkeling out through the surf]
Keep going a little further Owen, maybe somebody'll harpoon you!

[On the train]
I'm getting the hell out of here.
[Stands up and walks off]
Too god damn sultry in here.
Here. It's my favorite fuchsia. Live and be well.
Two minutes ago, you were my agent. and now you're telling me that...
Larry, I'm sorry. That's the way the mop flops.
That's what i get after seven years? That's the way the mop flops?
Larry, you have every right to feel like this is the lowest point in your entire life. Arnie, what are you doing? You're bending the fern. Don't bend the fern. Fluff it! Fluff it!
The night was... nt... oy. There's probably halibut, right here... who could write better than me. uh. oy. the night was... ya got a line fish, just yell it out. I'm up for grabs.
She didn't feel a thing, professor Donner. I know how important that is to you not to have her feel a thing.
Who?
Your wife. She had a little trouble walking, but that was from the gardener.
You saw my wife?
She was kind of a tart Larry. Although I can see why you married her. She was very beautiful.
Do you say the night was humid? Or do you say the night was moist? That's writing.
The night was sultry.
